buffer_config.notes: Rolling 52-week buffer. Array structure ready; auto-pruning deferred to Phase 1A.

regimes.report_context: First full trading week of 2026 analysis; rotation from Mag7 concentration toward breadth participation

intraweek_alerts.impact_description: December job creation weakest in years; household survey divergence noted; payroll growth decelerating sharply; labor softening trajectory confirmed.
10th consecutive month of manufacturing contraction; production and orders declining; inventory collapse signals demand weakness; primary bearish contributor to regime analysis.
Breadth expanding constructively; majority of S&P 500 stocks participating in rally; Mag7 concentration declining from 33% to 31%; rotation into Materials, Healthcare, Utilities confirmed.

regime.recession_probability_description: Moderate risk. Base TRANSITION probability 35% + manufacturing weakness (+4pp) + weakening labor (+3pp) + sticky wages (+2pp) - breadth improvement (-3pp) - tight credit (-2pp) - labor >4.0% (-2pp) = 22% net probability.

growth.description: Manufacturing sector contracted for 10th consecutive month (August 2025 â€“ January 2026). ISM PMI 47.9 (December 2025) signals continued economic weakness in industrial production. Production subindex 46.1, new orders 45.8, inventories 45.2 all reflect contraction. However, services sector remains resilient. Manufacturing weakness is structural but not systemic given breadth expansion elsewhere.

key_indicators.name: Inventory Index
key_indicators.implication: Rapid destocking; supply-side pressure or demand panic

drivers: US export headwinds (trade tensions, tariff expectations)
Capital goods cycle turning; capex decisions postponed
risks: Manufacturing contraction accelerates; ISM <47 sustained in Q1 2026
ISM heads further below 48; signals recession approaching
Services follow; composite PMI breaks below 50
supports: Breadth expansion suggests services/consumer still healthy
Labor market resilience offsets manufacturing drag
Credit markets loose; no deleveraging signals

labor.description: Labor market showing signs of softening but not deteriorating. Unemployment rate 4.4% (improved from 4.6%), signaling tightness in labor supply. However, December non-farm payrolls came in at only 50,000 jobs (weakest in years, vs. 73,000 expected), indicating job creation is decelerating. Continuing claims 1.914M (rising slightly). Wage growth 3.8% annualized remains elevated, which may limit Fed rate-cut aggressiveness. This is consistent with soft-landing scenario if hiring stabilizes; elevated recession risk if payroll weakness accelerates.

key_indicators.name: Unemployment Rate
key_indicators.implication: Labor market still tight; no major layoffs yet

key_indicators.name: Non-Farm Payrolls
key_indicators.implication: Job creation weakest in years; deceleration clear

key_indicators.name: Jobless Claims
key_indicators.implication: No surge but not declining; labor loosening slowly

key_indicators.name: Wage Growth
key_indicators.implication: Inflation pressures in wage demands; Fed cuts constrained

drivers: Manufacturing contraction reducing industrial job creation
Services/hospitality still hiring but at slower pace
risks: Non-farm payrolls decline further in coming months (<50K sustained)
Unemployment rate rises above 5.0% (recession threshold crossed)
Household-establishment survey divergence resolves to downside (HH shows weakness too)
supports: No widespread layoff announcements (tech companies stabilizing headcount)
Wage growth supports consumption; household balance sheets remain strong

inflation.description: Inflation trajectory disinflationary heading into 2026. Core CPI and PCE expected to remain well-controlled as shelter costs cool and energy stabilizes. However, wage growth at 3.8% may provide floor on inflation; sticky core services remain slight concern. Key binary risk: January 14, 2026 CPI print will be determinative for Fed messaging and equity market direction. Disinflationary print (0.2% MoM or lower) supports GROWTH path; sticky print (0.3%+ MoM) supports TRANSITION or DEFENSIVE persistence.

key_indicators.name: Core CPI (ex-food, energy)
key_indicators.implication: Core inflation cool; no sticky surprises yet

key_indicators.name: Shelter Costs
key_indicators.implication: Housing component normalizing after years of elevation

key_indicators.name: Wage Growth (YoY)
key_indicators.implication: Labor cost inflation remains above comfort zone

drivers: Fed rate cuts (75 bps total in 2025) creating disinflationary backdrop
Energy stability; no geopolitical oil shocks
Shelter component cooling as rent growth moderates
Wage growth sticky but not accelerating
risks: Wage acceleration surprises higher; sticky core services inflation
Oil price shock or tariff-driven commodity inflation
Shelter costs plateau before reaching 2% trend
supports: Core CPI trajectory lower; no reacceleration signals

financial_conditions.description: Credit markets exceptionally tight, reflecting minimal systemic stress and strong credit demand. IG spreads at 79 bps (tightest in 20 years), HY spreads at 279 bps (also historically compressed). This means: (1) No imminent credit stress or deleveraging risk, (2) Limited margin of safety if growth concerns mount, (3) Spreads have little room to compress further; significant room to widen if macro deteriorates. Credit markets are giving the all-clear signal on systemic risk; current equity weakness is tactical (profit-taking, rotation) rather than structural (credit crunch).

key_indicators.name: IG Credit Spreads
key_indicators.implication: Corporate credit demand strong; no stress signals

key_indicators.name: HY Credit Spreads
key_indicators.implication: High-yield credit healthy; risk appetite intact

key_indicators.name: VIX Level
key_indicators.implication: Equity volatility contained; no panic pricing

key_indicators.name: Yield Curve Slope (10Y-2Y)
key_indicators.implication: Curve constructively steep; financial conditions accommodative

drivers: Fed rate cuts (75 bps in 2025) reducing discount rates
Credit supply abundant; no tightening in lending standards
Equity market resilience = risk appetite intact
No major credit events or defaults (corporate health strong)
risks: Spreads widening sharply if growth data misses (IG >120 bps)
Credit event or default in leveraged corporate sector
Curve flattening if Fed signals pause on rate cuts
supports: IG spreads tightest in 20 years = healthy credit cycle
HY spreads compressed; high-yield issuance strong

sector_rankings.rationale: Materials leading rotation into cyclical assets as rate-cut cycle begins. Tariff expectations (potential upside to prices), capex cycle turning positive, precious metals benefiting from safe-haven demand (gold +67% YoY). Leading sector in TRANSITION regime.
key_catalysts: Tariff policy clarity (potential tailwind to commodity prices)
Capex recovery in Q1 2026 (infrastructure, defense spending)
risks: Tariff reversal or commodity price collapse

sector_rankings.rationale: Healthcare a reliable beneficiary of rate-cut environments (lower discount rates boost valuation multiples). Defensive characteristics make it attractive in TRANSITION regime. Earnings cycle durable; drug approvals steady pipeline. Aging population tailwind (structural).
key_catalysts: Earnings beats in biotech & medical devices

sector_rankings.rationale: Utilities benefiting from AI data center build-out (nuclear power demand rising). Rate-cut cycle supports bond-like characteristics (dividend yield becomes more attractive). Defensive positioning in TRANSITION regime; margin expansion from operational leverage.
key_catalysts: Nuclear capacity expansion (AI servers = sustained demand)
risks: Regulatory pressure on rate base (capex capex constraints)

sector_rankings.rationale: Industrials benefiting from defense spending and infrastructure tailwinds. Earnings cycle supports moderate allocation. Less cyclical than Materials but more exposed than Utilities. Good fit for TRANSITION regime.

Financials benefit from steeper yield curve (net interest margins improve). Credit spreads tight = low loan-loss provisions. Banking sector stabilized post-SVB; capital ratios elevated. Moderate allocation appropriate for TRANSITION regime; rate cuts may pressure margins later.

Consumer Discretionary neutral in TRANSITION regime. Household spending remains resilient but faces headwinds from wage growth moderation. Retail earnings mixed; luxury goods (Mag7 concentration) under pressure; mid-tier discretionary more attractive. Valuation stretched relative to fundamentals.
risks: Consumer spending slowdown if labor market cracks

sector_rankings.rationale: Real Estate lagging in TRANSITION regime. Office vacancy high; remote work structural headwind. Industrial REITs benefiting from e-commerce but retail REITs under pressure. Rate-cut cycle eventually helps (lower cap rates), but near-term pain from debt servicing and revaluations.
key_catalysts: Rate cuts boosting cap rates (valuation relief)
Dividend yields attractive at current levels
risks: Debt refinancing pressure if rates stay elevated

sector_rankings.rationale: Consumer Staples defensive but underweighting due to high valuations relative to growth. Trading premium to market due to defensive characteristics in TRANSITION regime. Earnings growth modest; margin pressure from input costs possible. Better as defensive hedge than core position.

Energy neutral in TRANSITION regime. Oil prices stable (~$82/bbl); geopolitical risks contained. Refining margins healthy but facing peak earnings risk. LNG export growth supporting upstream valuations. Dividend yields attractive; buyback programs robust.
key_catalysts: Oil prices stable or higher (geopolitical support)

sector_rankings.rationale: Communications (Meta, Google, Magnificent Seven concentration) under profit-taking pressure. Despite strong advertising fundamentals, valuations stretched; concentration risk elevated. YouTube, Instagram growth solid but facing competitive pressure (TikTok, short-form video). Regulatory risk persistent.
risks: TikTok ban or restrictions (Meta beneficiary but macro risk)

sector_rankings.rationale: Technology severely concentrated in Magnificent Seven (Nvda, Msft, Googl, Amzn, Tsla, Meta, Avgo), which are experiencing profit-taking after dominant 2024. Concentration >31% (vs. normal ~20%); breadth within sector weak (only 7 stocks driving returns). TRANSITION regime does not favor concentrated tech growth. AI narrative intact but valuations stretched; near-term consolidation likely.
key_catalysts: AI capex cycle peak (potential saturation concern)
risks: Regulatory antitrust action (Apple, Google, Meta, Amazon)
AI moat erosion (competition from open-source models)
sector_rankings.safe_haven_note: Magnificent Seven Mag7 core (NVDA, MSFT, GOOGL, AMZN, TSLA) should be held for quality/optionality but reduced on strength given valuation stretched positioning. Mag7 concentration at 31% warrants systematic trimming as rotation into Materials, Healthcare, Utilities continues.

stock_analyst_guidance.conviction_adjustment: Reduce cyclical conviction by 8pp; reduce growth-tech conviction by 12pp; boost defensive conviction by 5pp; boost value conviction by 8pp

size_hint_adjustments.growth_stocks: Cap at 4% max position size (vs normal 6%); conviction threshold 75 (vs normal 70)
size_hint_adjustments.cyclical_stocks: Normal 6% max; conviction threshold 75 (vs 70); require strong Materials/Industrials thesis
size_hint_adjustments.defensive_stocks: Allow 6% max; conviction threshold 65 (vs 70); Healthcare/Utilities favorable

stock_analyst_guidance.example_application: Tesla (growth cyclical in TRANSITION): Base conviction 78, regime penalty -12pp = 66pp conviction (MEDIUM-LOW). Position size capped at 4%. CAT (Materials cyclical in TRANSITION): Base conviction 72, regime boost +8pp = 80pp conviction (MEDIUM-HIGH). Position size normal 6%.

action_priority.action: OVERWEIGHT Materials sector; from 5% to 10%+ of equity allocation
action_priority.rationale: Materials #1 ranked sector; tariff upside; capex cycle turning; precious metals benefiting from safe-haven demand

action_priority.action: OVERWEIGHT Healthcare sector; from 10% to 14%+ of equity allocation
action_priority.rationale: Healthcare #2 ranked; defensive; rate-cut beneficiary; earnings durable; aging population tailwind

action_priority.action: OVERWEIGHT Utilities sector; from 6% to 10% of equity allocation
action_priority.rationale: Utilities #3 ranked; nuclear power demand (AI); rate-cut tailwind; dividend yield attractive

action_priority.action: REDUCE Technology sector; from 20% to 12-15% of equity allocation
action_priority.rationale: Technology #11 ranked; concentration risk excessive (Mag7 >31%); breadth weak; profit-taking pressure; valuation stretched

action_priority.action: TRIM Magnificent Seven holdings; reduce by 25% on 5% strength
action_priority.rationale: Mag7 concentration at 31% (vs normal 20%); systematic trimming = downside protection + source of capital for rotation

deployment_triggers.action: Deploy 3% of cash reserves into Materials/Healthcare on weakness
Maintain position; continue systematic Mag7 trimming
Deploy 5% cash into quality large-cap on panic

hedging_recommendation.vix_calls_ootm: Maintain 2% portfolio allocation in 3-month OTM VIX calls for tail-risk protection
hedging_recommendation.gold_silver_allocation: Maintain 3% portfolio allocation in precious metals for safe-haven hedge
hedging_recommendation.duration_positioning: Neutral; yield curve steepening supports duration-neutral stance
hedging_recommendation.put_spread_overlay: Optional; establish put spreads on Materials/Utilities (high conviction sectors) to reduce volatility

alpha_picks_analyst_guidance.conviction_adjustment_rule: In TRANSITION regime, apply -8pp to all growth-tech positions; apply +8pp to Materials, Healthcare, Utilities positions; apply 0pp to quality cyclicals

universe_filtering.cap_concentration: No single position >5% to avoid Mag7-style concentration risk

candidate_screening_rules.rule: Prefer Materials sector candidates (ISM weakness = capex cycle opportunity)
candidate_screening_rules.examples: FCX, Nucor, DD (diversified materials with capex tailwind)

candidate_screening_rules.rule: Prefer Healthcare candidates with earnings visibility
candidate_screening_rules.conviction_boost: +5pp for Healthcare stocks beating Q4 earnings

candidate_screening_rules.conviction_penalty: -12pp for any single Mag7 name >5% position
candidate_screening_rules.rationale: Concentration risk unwarranted in TRANSITION regime

candidate_screening_rules.rule: Avoid growth-tech unless thesis very strong (conviction >80)
candidate_screening_rules.examples: ASML, NVDA, META below 80pp conviction = UNDERWEIGHT

recession_probability_exceeds_50pct.action: Auto-shift to DEFENSIVE constraints: 45% equity, 40% bonds, 15% cash/hedges
recession_probability_exceeds_50pct.rationale: Elevated recession risk warrants capital preservation

breadth_reversal_confirmed.condition: If advance-decline ratio drops below 0.60 for 3 consecutive days
breadth_reversal_confirmed.action: Auto-execute 10% equity trim; shift proceeds to bonds/cash
breadth_reversal_confirmed.rationale: Breadth reversal signals regime shift to defensive

vix_spikes_above_25.condition: If VIX closes above 25 for 2 consecutive days
vix_spikes_above_25.action: Auto-execute sentiment extreme protocol (Section 5 of PROMPT_MARKET_DECISION_ENGINE)
vix_spikes_above_25.rationale: VIX above 25 = elevated volatility requiring immediate response

sector_cap_guidance.rationale: TRANSITION regime supports cap increases for Materials/Healthcare/Utilities; cap decreases for Tech/Communications

position_sizing_guidance.max_single_stock: 6% for quality large-cap; 4% for cyclical growth; 3% for speculative
position_sizing_guidance.breadth_requirement: Ensure >50 stocks represent 70% of equity returns (vs current concentration)

key_watch_items.condition: If CPI comes in at 0.2% MoM or lower, disinflationary soft landing confirmed
key_watch_items.market_response: Tech profit-taking reversal; Mag7 resumes upside; small-cap weakness reverses; VIX compression continues

key_watch_items.threshold: Powell signals patient stance on rate cuts; no hawkish pivot
key_watch_items.condition: If Powell/Fed signals comfort with rate-cut continuation, GROWTH path accelerates
key_watch_items.market_response: Equity risk premium compresses; PE multiple expansion; Bonds sell off (rates steepen, then flatten)

key_watch_items.condition: If ISM rebounds above 49 (Jan report = ~50), manufacturing contraction streak broken
key_watch_items.market_response: Cyclical outperformance accelerates; Materials, Industrials rotate higher; rate-cut momentum builds

key_watch_items.threshold: Tech earnings beat; Mag7 forward guidance upbeat (2026 growth >15%)
key_watch_items.condition: If Q4 earnings beat and Mag7 provides strong 2026 guidance, growth momentum restores
key_watch_items.market_response: Tech multiple re-rating upward; Mag7 resumes leadership; concentration risk returns

key_watch_items.threshold: CPI prints 0.4% MoM or higher; core CPI sticky
key_watch_items.condition: If CPI disappoints with sticky inflation, Fed pivot postponed; rate cuts delayed or reversed
key_watch_items.market_response: Equity selloff 3-5%; Bonds extend selloff (rates spike 30-50 bps); Gold rallies; Materials correction

key_watch_items.threshold: Non-farm payrolls <50K sustained for 2 months; unemployment >5.0%
key_watch_items.condition: If labor market cracks (payroll <50K + unemployment rising), recession signals flash
key_watch_items.market_response: Equity selloff 5-10%; Flight-to-safety (bonds, gold); VIX spikes >25; credit spreads widen 50+ bps

key_watch_items.threshold: ISM PMI <46 sustained; production & orders both contracting >3 points MoM
key_watch_items.condition: If ISM breaks below 46 (11th+ consecutive month contraction), recession probability >50%
key_watch_items.market_response: Cyclical sectors (-10%); Materials, Industrials capitulate; Treasury yields drop 50+ bps; equity VIX >25

key_watch_items.threshold: IG spreads widen to 150 bps; HY spreads spike to 450+ bps
key_watch_items.condition: If credit spreads blow out 50+ bps, systemic stress concerns mount
key_watch_items.market_response: Equity panic selling; deleveraging cascade; flight to Treasuries/gold; forced position liquidations

key_watch_items.threshold: Advance-decline ratio drops below 0.50; new highs-lows invert
key_watch_items.condition: If breadth deteriorates (A/D <0.50 sustained), market leadership breaks; downside acceleration likely
key_watch_items.market_response: Equity breadth collapse; Mag7 weakness spreads to broader market; volatility spike; rotation reversal

ism_manufacturing_pmI.impact: Low impact; ISM stable/trending; minor degradation if next report shows material change

non_farm_payrolls.impact: High relevance; latest labor market snapshot; near real-time analysis quality

unemployment_rate.impact: High relevance; current labor market conditions; near real-time analysis quality

credit_spreads.impact: Very high relevance; real-time credit market sentiment; current stress assessment

cpi_data.impact: Medium impact; January 14 report expected (5 days out); current data used; may be superseded soon

data_freshness_audit.analysis_note: Data freshness is adequate for regime classification. ISM PMI is 32 hours old (slightly past preferred 24-hour window) but ISM trends slowly; impact minimal. Labor data is fresh (20 hours old). Credit spreads very fresh (4 hours). CPI data aged but acceptable pending Jan 14 report. Overall data freshness supports TRANSITION regime confidence 0.72 without significant penalty.
